scenario: Across medieval regions, ports with larger dockyards also report higher urban literacy rates in surviving tax records.
claim: Larger dockyards cause higher literacy.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Richer trading regions could both afford larger dockyards and fund schools/scribes. The observed association does not establish that expanding dockyards would raise literacy.

scenario: In an archive of famous philosophers, those who were exiled appear to have produced more influential works than those who were not exiled.
claim: Exile makes philosophers more influential.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Philosophers who were exiled may have written more influential works, but we cannot determine if this is because they were exiled or because they were more influential to begin with.

scenario: Records show 65% of naval deaths in a war were sailors from the largest fleet. A commentator concludes that serving in the largest fleet was most dangerous.
claim: Serving in the largest fleet was the most dangerous assignment.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Raw death counts ignore the denominator. If the largest fleet contained most sailors, it can account for most deaths even with a lower death rate than smaller fleets.

scenario: Provinces with higher cathedral density also show higher grain yields in regional summaries compiled centuries later.
claim: Building more cathedrals increases grain yields.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The confounding variable is wealth. Wealthy regions can support both cathedral construction and high yields. The regional correlation does not show that cathedrals caused productivity improvements at the farm level.

scenario: States that historically minted silver coins are more likely to be high-income today.
claim: Minting silver coins historically leads to modern prosperity.
label: NO
gold_rationale: States that were able to mint silver coins are more likely to be alive today because they were prosperous. The states that weren't able to mint silver coins don't exist today.

scenario: A city observes that whenever it raises emergency grain imports, famine deaths still rise that year. The council proposes banning emergency imports to reduce famine.
claim: Banning emergency grain imports will reduce famine deaths.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Imports are typically increased in response to worsening harvests. The harvest failure drives deaths and also triggers imports, so stopping imports would likely worsen outcomes rather than improve them.

scenario: A kingdom notices that provinces receiving the most plague relief funds also have the highest death rates. The king decides to stop sending relief to reduce deaths.
claim: Stopping plague relief funds will reduce death rates.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Relief is directed toward the worst-hit provinces. Outbreak intensity drives both funding and deaths; withdrawing aid would not address the underlying severity and may increase mortality.

scenario: A ruler sees that regions with more pamphlet printing houses experience more sectarian conflict. He proposes shutting printing houses to end conflict.
claim: Shutting printing houses will eliminate sectarian conflict.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Places with sectarian tensions will naturally have more pamphlet printing hosues becase there are more people who want to express their opinions. Having more pamphlets will also cause more sectarian conflict because more people are expressing their opinions.

scenario: A general argues that building a massive border wall causes empires to collapse, since many walls were completed shortly before collapses. He advises canceling the wall project to save the empire.
claim: Canceling the wall project will prevent imperial collapse.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Walls are often built when threats are already existential. The threat drives both the construction decision and the heightened risk of collapse; canceling the wall does not remove the underlying danger.

scenario: A navy finds that admirals awarded gold epaulettes win more battles. Leadership mandates gold epaulettes for all captains to improve win rates.
claim: Mandating gold epaulettes will increase battle win rates.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Gold epaulettes likely signal seniority and proven competence, the omitted variable which drives winning. Changing uniforms does not create experience or strategic skill.

scenario: A parliament observes that crime spikes often happen after curfews are imposed. Legislators propose banning curfews to reduce crime.
claim: Banning curfews will reduce crime.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Curfews are typically imposed because unrest and crime are already escalating. The escalation drives both the policy response and observed crime levels. Banning the response does not address the cause.

scenario: A monarch notes that dynasties whose heirs adopted a specific auspicious title often had prosperous decades. She orders her heir to adopt the title to ensure prosperity.
claim: Adopting the auspicious title will cause national prosperity.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The association is likely confounded by underlying institutional strength or is a mere coincidence. A title change lacks a causal mechanism to drive economic prosperity.

scenario: A colonial governor observes that when he increases garrison size, rebellions still intensify. He concludes garrisons cause rebellion and proposes reducing troops.
claim: Reducing troop garrisons will reduce rebellion intensity.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: A feedback loop exists: troop increases may be a reaction to rebellion, but large garrisons can also inflame grievances. The net effect of reducing troops is uncertain without knowing which direction dominates.

scenario: A reformer sees that provinces with the strictest anti-corruption edicts have the worst corruption indices. He proposes abolishing anti-corruption offices because they 'cause corruption.'
claim: Abolishing anti-corruption offices will reduce corruption.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The offices are assigned where the corruption problem is most severe. This 'indication' (baseline corruption) causes both the intervention and the high observed corruption levels.

scenario: A ruler notices that regions receiving the most flood defenses still experience the most flood damage. He proposes stopping flood-defense spending.
claim: Stopping flood-defense spending will reduce flood damage.
label: NO
gold_rationale: High-risk areas are 'indicated' for defenses. The underlying risk drives both the spending and the damage; stopping the spending would likely increase damage, not decrease it.

scenario: A ministry mandates that all teachers focus on rote recitation to raise exam passage rates, because regions with more recitation drills have higher passage rates historically.
claim: Mandating rote recitation will increase true learning.
label: NO
gold_rationale: When a proxy (exam passage) becomes the target, it is gamed via rote drills, causing it to lose its relationship with the true objective (learning).

scenario: A government expands a draft to raise army size. After the draft, reported desertions rise. Officials claim the draft causes desertion and propose canceling the draft.
claim: Canceling the draft will reduce desertion rates.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The increase in reported desertions may be due to selective observation (increased monitoring) or external factors like war severity, rather than the draft itself.

scenario: A court notices that when it grants amnesties, political violence rises afterward. The king concludes amnesties cause violence and bans them.
claim: Banning amnesties will reduce political violence.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Amnesties are reactive interventions to rising violence. The underlying unrest causes both the amnesty and the subsequent violence; banning the response won't stop the trend.

scenario: A ruler subsidizes canal construction. Trade expands dramatically afterward. Critics argue the trade boom would have happened anyway because a new overseas colony began producing spices at scale.
claim: The canal subsidy caused the trade boom.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The trade boom is likely confounded by the spice supply shock. Without isolating these factors, the subsidy's causal role cannot be determined.

scenario: A kingdom bans taverns to reduce disorder. The next year, recorded assaults drop, but contemporaneous records show the police stopped patrolling tavern districts and moved to palace security.
claim: The tavern ban reduced assaults.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The drop in recorded assaults is likely due to selective observation (reduced patrols) rather than a true reduction in violence following the ban.

scenario: A province mandates Sunday schooling. Literacy rises afterward. A rival claims the true driver was the sudden availability of cheap paper from a new mill that lowered book prices.
claim: The Sunday school mandate caused the literacy rise.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the mandate or the technological shift was the primary driver of literacy gains.

scenario: An emperor reforms coinage to stabilize prices. Inflation continues because a war disrupted tax collection and forced emergency borrowing.
claim: The coinage reform failed to stabilize prices, so coinage reforms are ineffective.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Inflation was driven by an omitted war financing shock. The failure of the reform in this specific context does not prove coinage reforms are generally ineffective.

scenario: A state expands road building to integrate frontier regions. After roads, banditry reports increase. Ministers propose stopping road building to reduce banditry.
claim: Stopping road building will reduce banditry.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Roads create a feedback loop: they increase commerce (attracting bandits) but also increase state reach. Stopping road building might reduce reports without addressing the trade dynamics.

scenario: A court censors dissident songs. Public unrest appears to fall in official reports, but private letters describe widespread hidden organizing.
claim: Censoring dissident songs reduces unrest.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Censorship induces selective observation by suppressing signals of unrest. The reported drop is an artifact of the intervention, not a true reduction in underlying unrest.

scenario: A kingdom lowers tariffs during crises. Historical records show famines often follow tariff reductions. The king keeps tariffs high to avoid famine.
claim: Keeping tariffs high will prevent famine.
label: NO
gold_rationale: An omitted variable (crop failure) causes both the tariff reduction (a response) and the famine. Keeping tariffs high would actually worsen the shortage caused by the failure.

scenario: An emperor promotes a moral campaign against bribery. Soon after, reported bribery cases rise. He concludes the campaign increased bribery and ends it.
claim: Ending the anti-bribery campaign will reduce bribery.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Increased detection (selective observation) creates the illusion of more bribery. Ending the campaign would reduce detection, not the underlying crime.

scenario: A ruler institutes congestion tolls on a major bridge to reduce traffic. Drivers reroute to the other major bridge, and total travel time in the city increases. The ruler concludes tolls worsen congestion for the city.
claim: Bridge tolls increase overall congestion citywide.
label: YES
gold_rationale: In this scenario, the intervention successfully reveals a causal chain where adaptive rerouting increases travel time elsewhere. No trap is present; the effect follows the stated mechanism.

scenario: A kingdom introduces universal grain price caps. Merchants reduce shipments to avoid losses. Shortages worsen and riots increase.
claim: Grain price caps can increase shortages and riots by reducing supply.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The causal link from intervention to outcome is explicitly supported by merchant behavior described in the scenario. This is a valid interventional claim.

scenario: A republic mandates that historians only publish 'victory narratives' to raise morale. Over time, leaders make worse strategic decisions because losses are hidden.
claim: Mandating only victory narratives can worsen decision quality by distorting information.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Information distortion is a plausible causal mechanism linking censorship to poor decision outcomes. The scenario provides a consistent interventional logic.

scenario: A monarch increases taxes to fund irrigation. Harvests improve afterward, but climate records show rainfall also increased substantially that period.
claim: The tax-funded irrigation caused the harvest improvement.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Harvest yields are confounded by the omitted variable of rainfall. The separate contributions of irrigation and weather cannot be disentangled without further comparison.

scenario: A capital launches an anti-plague quarantine. After implementation, deaths still climb for weeks because infections were already widespread. Critics claim quarantine increases deaths and demand repeal.
claim: Repealing quarantine will reduce plague deaths.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Quarantine is a reactive intervention to an already widespread outbreak. The trend in deaths is driven by existing infections; repealing the response will not reduce the death toll.

scenario: A ruler mandates that all provinces submit weekly productivity reports. Reported productivity rises, but letters suggest officials falsified numbers to avoid punishment.
claim: Weekly reporting mandates increase true productivity.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The productivity metric gamed by officials has drifted away from true productivity (Proxy Drift). Reporting increases while the underlying reality remains unchanged or worsened.

scenario: A republic outsources tax collection to private contractors. Revenues rise, but corruption scandals also rise because audits became more frequent and transparent.
claim: Outsourcing tax collection increases corruption.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The rise in scandals is likely due to selective observation (better audits) rather than an increase in underlying corruption. Causal attribution is therefore ambiguous.

scenario: A kingdom funds a new port to expand trade. Trade rises, but only because a nearby rival port was destroyed by an earthquake the same year.
claim: The new port funding caused the trade increase.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Trade shifted due to the omitted variable of the rival port's destruction. The port funding coincided with an external shock that drove the observed outcome.

scenario: A state imposes harsh penalties for grain hoarding. After the law, hoarding reports drop, but black-market activity rises and shortages persist.
claim: Harsh penalties eliminated hoarding and improved food availability.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Selective observation shows a drop in reported hoarding while true behavior shifts to unobserved black markets. Food availability did not actually improve.

scenario: A city increases public punishments to deter theft. Theft reports fall immediately, but merchant letters say victims stopped reporting due to fear of being questioned publicly.
claim: Public punishments reduced theft.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The drop in reports is due to selective observation (fear of reporting) rather than a true deterrent effect on theft.

scenario: A ruler mandates standardized weights and measures. Market disputes decline sharply after the mandate.
claim: Standardizing weights and measures reduces market disputes.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Standardization is a direct causal lever to reduce transaction ambiguity. No confounding or selection issues are indicated in this valid interventional claim.

scenario: A city subsidizes shipbuilding. Naval power increases, but only wealthy merchant guilds capture the subsidies and expand private fleets that the state cannot command.
claim: Shipbuilding subsidies increased state naval power.
label: NO
gold_rationale: State power is confounded by the omitted variable of private capture. The subsidy increased private capacity but did not causally translate to state naval command.

scenario: A state bans duel culture to reduce elite deaths. Elite deaths fall, but broader violence rises because grievances shift to factional assassinations.
claim: Banning duels can reduce elite deaths but increase other forms of political violence.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario identifies a displacement effect that is a valid causal consequence of the intervention. The claim follows the interventional logic described.

scenario: A reformist leader is elected and detente follows. The state was also facing severe fiscal crisis and declining growth.
claim: If the reformist leader had not been elected, detente would not have occurred.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Structural constraints (Late Preemption) might have made detente inevitable regardless of the leader's election. The causal necessity of the leader in the counterfactual world is uncertain.

scenario: Archaeological data shows that ancient civilizations with complex irrigation systems also had high rates of temple construction. A researcher suggests irrigation causes religious fervor.
claim: Complex irrigation systems lead to increased religious fervor.
label: NO
gold_rationale: High state administrative capacity (Z) is a common cause for both large-scale infrastructure like irrigation (X) and monumental architecture like temples (Y). The correlation is likely spurious.

scenario: In the 18th century, regions with high coffee consumption showed a higher frequency of political pamphlets.
claim: Increasing coffee consumption in a region will cause more political pamphlets to be written.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While coffee houses provided a venue for discourse, urbanization and literacy are significant confounders (Z). Without controlling for these, the causal impact of coffee (X) on pamphlet production (Y) is ambiguous.

scenario: Records show that years with unusually high pirate activity in the Caribbean coincided with high global temperatures.
claim: Piracy in the Caribbean causes global cooling.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This is a classic spurious correlation. There is no plausible causal mechanism linking pirate activity (X) to global temperature changes (Y); both are likely driven by independent historical and natural cycles.

scenario: Data from the 19th century shows that cities with more chimneys had higher life expectancy than rural villages with no chimneys.
claim: Installing more chimneys in a home increases the lifespan of the inhabitants.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The number of chimneys (X) is a proxy for wealth and industrial development (Z). Wealthier cities had better sanitation and food security, which improved life expectancy (Y), regardless of chimney count.

scenario: Historical annals note that whenever a comet appeared in the sky, a major monarch died within the year.
claim: The appearance of a comet predicts the death of a monarch.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This is likely due to historical filtering/selective recording (Z). Chroniclers often recorded 'omens' (X) only when a significant event (Y) occurred to justify it post-hoc, ignoring comets that were not followed by deaths.

scenario: States with high cavalry-to-infantry ratios often won battles in the 15th century. A military analyst claims cavalry ratio is the primary driver of victory.
claim: Increasing the cavalry-to-infantry ratio will ensure victory in 15th-century warfare.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While cavalry (X) is effective, its success (Y) is highly dependent on terrain and the state's ability to maintain horses (Z). Without accounting for terrain suitability, the causal link is not guaranteed.

scenario: A revolutionary government bans all foreign newspapers to stop the spread of 'counter-revolutionary' ideas. Six months later, local protests increase.
claim: Banning foreign newspapers increased local protests.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the ban (X) caused the protests (Y) or if both were driven by worsening economic conditions or other unobserved factors (Z). The intervention's direct effect is confounded by the timing of other events.

scenario: A city-state observes that whenever they raise taxes on grain, the city experiences a bread riot. They decide to lower taxes to zero to permanently eliminate riots.
claim: A zero-tax policy on grain will permanently eliminate bread riots.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Bread riots (Y) are primarily caused by grain scarcity (Z). While taxes (X) increase prices, eliminating them will not prevent riots if a harvest failure occurs, as the underlying cause of the shortage remains.

scenario: An empire mandates that all border regions build stone walls to prevent nomadic raids. Raids in those regions drop, but increase significantly in neighboring un-walled friendly territories.
claim: Stone walls reduce the total number of raids against the empire's interests.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) merely displaced the raids (Z) to softer targets rather than reducing the motivation or capacity of the raiders. Total security (Y) may not have improved.

scenario: A colonial power builds schools in provinces where literacy is already rising due to missionary activity. They claim their school-building program is the reason for the literacy boom.
claim: The government school-building program caused the rise in literacy.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The program (X) was 'indicated' by areas already seeing success. The existing missionary education (Z) drove both the literacy (Y) and the decision to build more schools in those successful areas.

scenario: A medieval king implements a law requiring all knights to own a specific high-quality shield. Mortality among knights in the next war drops. Chroniclers credit the shield law.
claim: The shield mandate caused the reduction in knight mortality.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the shields (X) were the cause or if the next war was simply less lethal (Y) due to different enemy tactics or a shift in how battles were fought (Z). More data on the wars is needed.

scenario: To combat inflation, a state fixes the price of meat. Meat disappears from official markets but is widely available in secret 'back-alley' markets at five times the fixed price.
claim: Fixing meat prices effectively reduces the cost of meat for the population.
label: NO
gold_rationale: By targeting the 'official price' (static metric), the policy (X) caused a displacement where the actual cost for consumers (Y) rose due to scarcity and black-market premiums (Z).

scenario: A general introduces a 'decimation' policy (punishing every 10th man) to stop desertion. Desertion reports fall. He concludes the policy worked perfectly.
claim: The decimation policy reduced desertion rates.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The fall in reported desertion (Y) may be due to selective observation; commanders might stop reporting desertions to avoid the harsh group punishment (X), even if soldiers are still fleeing.

scenario: A region implements a mandatory vaccination program for smallpox. In the following decade, smallpox deaths drop to zero.
claim: The mandatory vaccination program caused the elimination of smallpox deaths.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Vaccination (X) is a well-established direct causal intervention for reducing viral mortality (Y). In this scenario, the direct causal link from intervention to the expected outcome is logical and supported.

scenario: An emperor creates a 'Public Integrity Bureau' to investigate tax collectors. Reported embezzlement drops significantly. He claims the bureau successfully stopped corruption.
claim: The Integrity Bureau reduced tax embezzlement.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is ambiguous whether embezzlement (Y) actually decreased or if corrupt officials simply became more sophisticated at hiding it or bribing the new investigators (X/Z).

scenario: A kingdom increases patrols on the King's Highway to stop banditry. Bandit attacks on the highway drop. Simultaneously, attacks on secondary roads and trade paths double.
claim: Increasing highway patrols reduced the total number of bandits in the kingdom.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) changed the location of the outcome (X causes Y-local) but did not address the source of the problem. Bandits simply substituted their targets (Z), leaving total numbers (Y) potentially unchanged.

scenario: Historians note that empires that adopted 'Standard Calendar A' had longer periods of internal peace than those that didn't. A new kingdom adopts the calendar to ensure stability.
claim: Adopting Standard Calendar A causes internal peace.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Adopting a standardized calendar (X) is a symptom of existing administrative cohesion (Z). The calendar itself is a symbolic tool, not the causal driver of peace (Y).

scenario: A province lowers property taxes to encourage farm development. Agricultural output rises, but a major new canal also opened in the province the same year.
claim: The tax reduction caused the rise in agricultural output.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Both the tax cut (X) and the new canal (Z) could drive output (Y). Without controlling for the canal's impact, the causal effect of the tax reduction is ambiguous.

scenario: A naval commander changes the layout of ships to prioritize speed over armor. In the next three skirmishes, he wins all three. He claims speed is the deciding factor in naval combat.
claim: Prioritizing speed over armor increases the probability of naval victory.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The victories (Y) could be due to favorable weather or inexperienced enemies in those specific skirmishes (Z). The causal link from ship speed (X) to victory requires broader testing.

scenario: A state implements a policy of public execution for counterfeiters. After the law, the number of counterfeit coins found in the capital drops to nearly zero, but remains high in the provinces.
claim: Public executions effectively deterred counterfeiting in the capital.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It's unclear if counterfeiting (Y) stopped or if counterfeiters simply moved their operations to the provinces to avoid the capital's scrutiny (Z). The total volume of crime might be unchanged.

scenario: A country institutes a mandatory 'Day of Silence' to reduce social friction. Social friction indices rise because people feel isolated and unable to resolve minor disputes.
claim: Mandatory silence can increase social friction by preventing dispute resolution.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario outlines a logical causal mechanism: removing communication (X) leads to unresolved and compounding friction (Y).

scenario: A reformist king bans 'selling of offices.' Efficiency in the bureaucracy increases. He claims the ban caused the improvement.
claim: Banning the sale of offices increases bureaucratic efficiency.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: If the king also introduced merit exams (Z) at the same time, the improvement (Y) might be due to the exams rather than just the ban (X). The two interventions are confounded.

scenario: A researcher finds that when ancient armies used 'Symbol X' on their shields, they were 20% more likely to win. He recommends a modern ceremonial unit adopt the symbol to improve performance.
claim: Adopting Symbol X will improve unit performance.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Historically, Symbol X (X) was likely reserved for elite, well-trained units (Z). The symbol is a marker of performance, not a cause of it (Y). Giving it to a non-elite unit won't change their skill.

scenario: A city enacts a law banning the dumping of waste in the river. Disease rates fall dramatically within two years.
claim: Banning river waste dumping reduces disease rates.
label: YES
gold_rationale: There is a direct and scientifically sound causal chain: reducing waste (X) improves water quality (Z), which reduces waterborne illness (Y). This is a valid interventional claim.

scenario: An official observes that the lowest-performing schools in the empire are the ones receiving the 'Special Educational Grant.' He proposes cutting the grant to improve performance.
claim: Cutting the Special Educational Grant will improve school performance.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The grants (X) are given specifically to schools that are struggling (Z). The struggle (Z) causes the grant, not the other way around. Cutting it would likely make performance (Y) worse.

scenario: A state begins paying bounties for the heads of 'poisonous snakes.' People start breeding snakes in their basements to collect more bounty money. The number of snakes in the city increases.
claim: Paying snake bounties reduces the snake population.
label: NO
gold_rationale: When a proxy (dead snakes) is targeted (X), individuals game the metric by breeding more snakes (Z). This leads to an outcome (Y) opposite to the intended one.

scenario: A province builds new granaries to protect against famine. A famine occurs anyway three years later due to an unprecedented five-year drought. The project is labeled a failure.
claim: Granaries are ineffective at reducing famine risk.
label: NO
gold_rationale: A massive omitted variable (extreme drought, Z) overwhelmed the intervention (X). The failure in an outlier event does not mean the intervention is ineffective for standard risks (Y).

scenario: A ruler offers tax breaks to any family with more than five children to increase the population. Ten years later, the census shows a massive population boom. Critics point out that the borders were also opened to refugees that same decade.
claim: The tax breaks caused the population boom.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The growth (Y) is confounded by the open-border policy (Z). It's impossible to tell if the tax breaks (X) had a greater impact without more detailed demographic data.

scenario: An army switches from bronze to iron weapons. In the next decade, they expand their borders significantly. Military historians claim iron weapons were the cause of expansion.
claim: Iron weapons cause military expansion.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Expansion (Y) could be caused by iron weapons (X) or by the simultaneous decline of neighboring powers (Z). The causal attribution to the metal type alone is not definitive.

scenario: A state subsidizes 'Alchemist Laboratories' to find a way to turn lead into gold. No gold is produced, but the chemists accidentally discover a new, more effective gunpowder formula.
claim: Subsidizing alchemists can lead to military technology breakthroughs.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario describes a valid interventional outcome where funding research (X) led to a breakthrough (Y), even if the breakthrough was not the intended one.

scenario: A city installs street lamps to reduce night-time crime. Crime reports rise. The mayor claims the lamps invited more criminals.
claim: Installing street lamps increases night-time crime.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The lamps (X) allow victims and patrols to see and report crimes that were previously hidden (Z). The rise in reports (Y) is due to better observation, not necessarily an increase in actual crime.

scenario: A tribe migrates from a fertile valley to a harsh desert. Within a generation, their mortality rate increases.
claim: Migrating to a desert environment increases mortality.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Resource scarcity in deserts (Z) is a direct causal driver of health outcomes. The intervention (moving, X) directly leads to the outcome (Y) through established ecological mechanisms.

scenario: A merchant guild restricts membership to only those who have never lost a ship. They claim their training program makes merchants more successful.
claim: The guild's training program prevents ship losses.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The low loss rate (Y) is an artifact of the selection criteria (only successful people are allowed in, Z) rather than the causal result of the guild's training (X).

scenario: A state begins paying bounties for the heads of 'poisonous snakes.' People start breeding snakes in their basements to collect more bounty money. The number of snakes in the city increases.
claim: Paying snake bounties reduces the snake population.
label: NO
gold_rationale: When a proxy (dead snakes) is targeted (X), individuals game the metric by breeding more snakes (Z). This leads to an outcome (Y) opposite to the intended one.

scenario: An ancient physician finds that all patients who survived a fever had eaten 'Herb Y.' He begins prescribing it to everyone with a fever. Mortality rates stay the same.
claim: Prescribing Herb Y will reduce fever mortality.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The physician only sampled the survivors (Outcome-Driven Selection, Z). If patients who died also ate the herb (X), it has no causal benefit on survival (Y).

scenario: A king mandates that all laws be written in 'The Common Tongue' so people understand them better. Legal disputes increase because people now have access to the courts and can argue about wording.
claim: Mandating a common tongue for laws increases legal transparency and access.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario identifies a logical outcome: more access (X) leading to more disputes (Y) as people utilize their new ability to interpret the law.

scenario: A reformer sets up 'Workhouses' to eliminate poverty. Poverty rates increase because the workhouses provide food, attracting the poor from surrounding regions.
claim: Workhouses cause an increase in the local poor population.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) acted as a pull factor for migration (Z), which directly caused the increase in the measured outcome (Y). This is a consistent interventional effect.

scenario: A general orders his men to stop wearing heavy helmets after seeing that most wounded soldiers in the hospital have head injuries. He believes helmets are making them more vulnerable.
claim: Removing helmets will reduce head injuries in battle.
label: NO
gold_rationale: This is survivorship bias. Soldiers with helmets survive head wounds and end up in hospitals (Z). Those without helmets die on the field and are not counted among the 'wounded.' Removing helmets (X) will increase deaths.

scenario: A city enacts a ban on theater performances to prevent 'moral decay.' A decade later, the city is sacked by a rival. Critics say the ban weakened the city's spirit and caused the defeat.
claim: Banning theater caused the military defeat.
label: NO
gold_rationale: A military defeat (Y) is a complex event driven by structural factors (Z). Attributing it to a cultural policy (X) is a stretch without a clear causal mechanism.

scenario: A state establishes a 'Maritime Insurance Office.' Overseas trade increases. Officials claim the insurance office created the boom.
claim: The creation of a Maritime Insurance Office causes trade expansion.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It's unclear if the office (X) caused the boom or if the office was created because trade (Y) was already expanding due to external factors (Z).

scenario: A historian argues that if the Archduke Ferdinand had not been assassinated in 1914, World War I would not have occurred.
claim: If the assassination had failed, the Great War would have been avoided.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Historical structuralism suggests the alliance systems (Z) were so tense that any trigger might have caused the war (Y). It's ambiguous if the specific assassination (X) was necessary.

scenario: The Great Library of Alexandria was destroyed. Modern scholars claim its preservation would have led to an industrial revolution 1000 years earlier.
claim: If the Library of Alexandria hadn't been destroyed, the industrial revolution would have happened by 800 AD.
label: NO
gold_rationale: An industrial revolution (Y) requires specific economic and labor conditions (Z). These conditions 'preempted' the possibility of an early revolution, regardless of the library (X).

scenario: In 1588, the Spanish Armada was hit by a massive storm. A historian claims that if the storm hadn't happened, Spain would have conquered England.
claim: If the storm had not occurred, England would have been conquered by Spain.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While the storm (X) was significant, England's navy was already outperforming Spain's (Z). Whether the Spanish could have successfully landed (Y) is counterfactually uncertain.

scenario: A bullet missed a revolutionary leader by an inch. If he had died, the revolution would have collapsed. He was the only one with the charisma to hold the factions together.
claim: If the leader had died, the revolution would have failed.
label: YES
gold_rationale: In a contingency-heavy scenario where a single person is the 'linchpin' (X) of a movement, their removal is logically sufficient to cause the collapse (Y) of the dependent outcome.

scenario: A king dies without an heir, leading to a civil war. If he had eaten a slightly different meal that didn't contain a specific pathogen, he would have lived to produce an heir.
claim: If the king had not eaten that specific meal, the civil war would have been avoided.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Even if he lived, there is no guarantee he would have produced an heir (Z). The counterfactual 'avoidance' of war (Y) depends on several other uncertain future events.

scenario: A spy is caught carrying plans for an invasion. The invasion is canceled. A strategist claims that if the spy hadn't been caught, the invasion would have succeeded by surprise.
claim: If the spy hadn't been caught, the invasion would have been a success.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Surprise (X) is an advantage, but not a guarantee of success (Y). Other factors like defender strength and logistics (Z) could still have caused failure.

scenario: A scientist is about to publish a discovery but dies in a carriage accident. The discovery is not made for another fifty years.
claim: If the carriage accident had not happened, the discovery would have been made fifty years earlier.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Since the discovery was already complete and ready for publication (X), the accident is the only factor preempting the outcome (Y). Its removal logically restores the outcome.

scenario: Napoleon lost at Waterloo. Some say if he had attacked two hours earlier, before the Prussians arrived, he would have won.
claim: If Napoleon had attacked two hours earlier, he would have won the Battle of Waterloo.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Attacking earlier (X) might have prevented the Prussian link-up, but the terrain (Z) was too muddy for a quick victory (Y). The counterfactual remains a subject of intense debate.

scenario: A message for a general is intercepted by the enemy, leading to a trap. If the messenger had taken the forest path instead of the road, he wouldn't have been caught.
claim: If the messenger had taken the forest path, the general would have received the message.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario assumes the enemy was only patrolling the road. If the forest path (X) was safe, the counterfactual removal of the 'interception' event leads directly to delivery (Y).

scenario: The Roman Empire collapsed. Some argue if lead pipes hadn't been used, the population would have been healthy enough to stop the barbarian invasions.
claim: The use of lead pipes was the necessary cause of the Roman Empire's collapse.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Structural issues like economic crisis (Z) were likely sufficient to cause the collapse (Y) regardless of lead poisoning (X). This is a case of Late Preemption.

scenario: Archaeologists observe that ancient settlements located near salt mines typically have much higher rates of adult literacy compared to those far from salt deposits.
claim: The presence of salt mines in a region causes an increase in adult literacy.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Salt was a high-value commodity in antiquity. Salt mines (X) generated significant regional wealth (Z), which funded education and trade bureaucracies that required literacy (Y). The correlation is confounded by the underlying economic prosperity.

scenario: Records from a 14th-century parish show that years with the highest church attendance also saw the highest rainfall for crops.
claim: Increased church attendance causes higher rainfall.
label: NO
gold_rationale: There is no plausible causal link between human attendance at a building (X) and meteorological precipitation patterns (Y). The correlation is spurious or driven by independent environmental cycles (Z).

scenario: A study of 10th-century artifacts shows that cultures with highly sophisticated silk-weaving techniques also had more frequent military victories.
claim: Developing sophisticated silk-weaving leads to military success.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Strong state administrative capacity (Z) is required to manage both complex luxury industries like silk (X) and large, well-organized military campaigns (Y). (Z) is the common cause.

scenario: Maritime records suggest that ships featuring elaborate gold-leaf figureheads were 30% more likely to survive trans-oceanic voyages than those with simple wooden figureheads.
claim: Elaborate gold-leaf figureheads provide a protective effect for ships at sea.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Ships with gold-leaf figureheads (X) belonged to wealthy fleets that could afford better-quality timber, professional crews, and regular maintenance (Z). It is the ship quality, not the figurehead, that drives survival (Y).

scenario: Data from the Han Dynasty shows that households owning more than three bronze mirrors had a significantly higher average life expectancy than those with none.
claim: Owning bronze mirrors increases a person's lifespan.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Bronze mirrors (X) were luxury items. Wealthy households (Z) had access to better food, sanitation, and physical security, which directly increased life expectancy (Y). (X) is merely a proxy for wealth.

scenario: In late medieval Europe, cities with a higher estimated population of domestic cats recorded fewer instances of plague-related deaths in specific years.
claim: A high domestic cat population is a primary driver of reduced plague mortality.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While cats (X) prey on rats (Z) which carry the plague, it is unclear if the cat population alone was sufficient to impact mortality (Y) or if other factors like quarantine and sanitation (Z) were more decisive.

scenario: To raise revenue without taxing the poor directly, a kingdom implements a 'Window Tax' based on the number of windows in a house. Consequently, new houses are built with almost no windows, and existing windows are bricked up.
claim: The Window Tax successfully increases tax revenue while maintaining housing quality.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The tax (X) targeted a specific metric (windows). Homeowners gamed the metric (Z) to avoid the tax, which directly degraded housing quality (Y) by removing light and ventilation.

scenario: A colonial governor offers a bounty for every wolf ear brought to the capital to eradicate wolves. Within two years, the number of ears submitted triples, but the wolf population in the wild remains unchanged.
claim: The bounty program is an effective way to reduce the wild wolf population.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The policy (X) created an incentive for 'gaming.' People began breeding wolves in captivity (Z) to harvest ears for the bounty, meaning the wild population (Y) was never truly impacted.

scenario: An empire mandates that all applicants for the Imperial Bureaucracy must pass a rigorous exam in ancient Latin. They note that bureaucrats hired after this mandate have higher performance reviews.
claim: Studying ancient Latin directly improves bureaucratic performance.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The exam (X) serves as a selection filter for highly educated and disciplined individuals (Z). These individuals would likely perform well (Y) regardless of the specific subject matter they were tested on.

scenario: A coastal nation builds twenty new lighthouses to aid navigation. Trade volume increases significantly in the following decade.
claim: Building lighthouses caused the increase in trade volume.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While lighthouses (X) facilitate trade (Y), the boom could be due to a general period of economic growth or the end of a war (Z). Without accounting for these factors, the causal weight of (X) is ambiguous.

scenario: A king bans the practice of dueling among nobles to preserve his officer corps. In the following years, noble mortality in the officer corps drops by 15%.
claim: The ban on dueling directly caused the reduction in noble mortality.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The mortality drop (Y) might be caused by the ban (X), but it could also result from changes in how wars were fought or better medical care for battlefield wounds (Z).

scenario: A central government takes over all private mints and issues a single, standardized currency. This eliminates the previous confusion caused by varying coin weights and values.
claim: Centralizing coinage reduces market transaction costs and confusion.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Standardization (X) directly removes the informational barrier (Z) that created high transaction costs (Y). This is a direct and logical interventional outcome.

scenario: A government begins heavily subsidizing domestic shipyards. Five years later, the nation's merchant marine has doubled in size.
claim: Subsidizing shipyards caused the growth of the merchant marine.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the subsidies (X) drove the growth (Y) or if the growth was already occurring due to global demand (Z), prompting the government to support an already-expanding industry.

scenario: During a plague outbreak, a city implements strict quarantine zones and mandatory hand-washing for merchants. The infection rate in the city remains lower than in neighboring un-quarantined cities.
claim: Quarantine and sanitation measures reduce the spread of the plague.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) physically disrupts the known transmission vectors (Z) of pathogens, leading to a direct and predictable reduction in the infection rate (Y).

scenario: An emperor decides to pay soldiers in land rather than gold to ensure their long-term loyalty. However, the available land is in hostile frontier regions, and desertion rates increase.
claim: Paying soldiers in land increases military desertion.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) provided a payment that carried high risk and low immediate value (Z), which directly incentivized soldiers to abandon their service (Y).

scenario: A state prohibits the import of tea to favor domestic herbal infusions. The official tea trade drops to zero, but the number of arrests for smuggling tea on the coast increases tenfold.
claim: Prohibiting tea imports eliminates tea consumption in the state.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The ban (X) only targeted the 'official' channel. The outcomeactual consumption (Y)likely persisted or increased via smuggling (Z), making the 'zero' official trade figure a misleading metric.

scenario: A kingdom establishes a national scientific society. In the following twenty years, the number of patents filed in the kingdom increases significantly.
claim: The creation of the scientific society caused the rise in patent activity.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the society (X) fostered the innovation (Y) or if the society was created in response to a pre-existing boom in invention and industrial growth (Z).

scenario: To better control a restive province, an empire builds high-quality paved roads connecting the provincial capital to military outposts. Rebellion frequency in the province remains high, but rebels are now much faster at moving between cities.
claim: Building roads in a province reduces the frequency and effectiveness of rebellions.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) created infrastructure that was intended for control but was also usable by the insurgents (Z). This feedback loop meant the roads (X) potentially increased the effectiveness (Y) of the very thing they were built to stop.

scenario: A city mandates that all wood-framed houses must have fire insurance. Following this, the number of reported house fires in the city increases by 40%.
claim: Mandatory fire insurance increases the risk of fires in a city.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is ambiguous whether the insurance (X) caused arson or carelessness (moral hazard, Z), or if owners simply became more diligent about reporting (Y) every minor fire now that they could claim benefits.

scenario: A nation abolishes serfdom. Over the next generation, industrial output triples. Supporters claim the liberation of labor drove the industrial revolution.
claim: Abolishing serfdom is the primary cause of industrial growth.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While freeing labor (X) is important, the boom (Y) might also be due to technological shifts or an influx of capital (Z) that happened concurrently. The specific contribution of (X) is hard to isolate.

scenario: A ruler establishes a single state religion to create social unity. Historical analysis shows that states with a single state religion often have fewer internal civil wars than multi-religious states.
claim: Establishing a state religion causes an increase in social cohesion and peace.
label: NO
gold_rationale: States that can successfully establish a single religion (X) usually already possess a high degree of cultural and ethnic homogeneity (Z). This existing homogeneity (Z) is the true cause of the peace (Y).

scenario: An empire implements a national postal system with fixed routes. literacy rates in the provinces begin to climb shortly after.
claim: Implementing a postal system causes literacy to rise.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The postal system (X) provides a reason to be literate, but the rise in literacy (Y) might also be driven by concurrent school construction or economic changes (Z) that made writing necessary for business.

scenario: To preserve timber for the navy, a kingdom limits the amount of forest land that can be cleared for farming. As a result, the price of timber stabilizes but the price of bread increases due to limited farmland.
claim: Forest clearing restrictions successfully stabilized timber prices but negatively impacted food costs.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) directly restricted the expansion of farmland (Z), which in turn reduced grain supply and raised bread prices (Y). This is a logical causal sequence.

scenario: A country bans child labor in factories. School enrollment rates for children under 12 increase by 50% in the following decade.
claim: The ban on child labor caused the increase in school enrollment.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The ban (X) certainly pushed children out of factories, but enrollment (Y) might only have been possible because adult wages rose or more schools were built (Z). Both factors are likely involved.

scenario: An army introduces the longbow as its primary infantry weapon. They win several major battles against heavily armored knights. The king credits the weapon's range for the victories.
claim: Using longbows increases the probability of victory against heavy armor.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Longbows (X) require years of training to use effectively. The victories (Y) may be due to the fact that the army consisted of long-service, elite professionals (Z) rather than the weapon itself.

scenario: A monarch begins granting city charters that provide legal independence to merchant guilds. These cities soon become the wealthiest in the realm.
claim: Granting city charters causes an increase in urban wealth.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the charters (X) created the wealth (Y) or if the monarch only granted charters to cities that were already becoming wealthy and powerful (Z) to secure their political support.

scenario: A revolutionary council mandates the use of the metric system for all commercial transactions to simplify trade. Market participants report that the time required to complete trades is reduced.
claim: Standardizing measurements reduces transaction time in markets.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Standardization (X) removes the need for complex conversions (Z) between varying local weights, directly lowering the time needed (Y) to finalize a sale.

scenario: A state implements a heavy 'Bachelor Tax' on unmarried men over 25. Marriage rates rise, but the number of separations and family disputes also increases.
claim: A bachelor tax effectively increases stable marriage rates.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The tax (X) increased the number of marriages (Y-volume), but it also incentivized marriages for tax avoidance (Z). This might mean the 'stability' of the marriages (Y-quality) actually decreased.

scenario: A city-state builds five new municipal hospitals with modern sanitation. Mortality from water-borne diseases in the city drops by half.
claim: Building municipal hospitals reduces mortality from water-borne disease.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Improved infrastructure (X) provides direct access to cleaner water and medical intervention (Z), which are known to causally reduce death rates (Y) from infection.

scenario: A religious authority bans the practice of usury (lending with interest). Capital for new business ventures becomes scarce in the official economy, but flourishing 'loan-pawn' shops appear.
claim: Banning usury effectively stops interest-based lending.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The ban (X) may not have stopped the practice (Y), but instead caused lenders to relabel interest as 'fees' or 'gift-back' structures (Z), making the actual effect on lending ambiguous.

scenario: A city-state funds the work of master painters and architects. A century later, it is hailed as the center of a cultural renaissance.
claim: State subsidies for artists cause a cultural renaissance.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Subsidies (X) are a factor, but a renaissance (Y) usually requires a confluence of wealth, new ideas, and political stability (Z). Whether (X) alone is the cause is debatable.

scenario: A dictator establishes a pervasive secret police force to monitor dissent. The number of public protests drops to zero. He claims he has achieved total social harmony.
claim: Secret police forces successfully eliminate political dissent.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The 'zero protests' (Y) is a measure of public expression, not actual sentiment. The police (X) drove the dissent underground (Z), so the visible lack of it is due to selective observation of only 'public' spaces.

scenario: A nation raises tariffs on imported iron to protect its own mines. Local iron production increases, but the cost of building tools and machinery in the nation also rises sharply.
claim: High tariffs on iron cause a rise in the cost of domestic industrial production.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The tariff (X) contributed to the cost (Y), but the magnitude depends on whether local mines are efficient or if energy costs (Z) for smelting also rose independently.

scenario: A kingdom mandates that all children be vaccinated for smallpox. In the following twenty years, smallpox deaths vanish entirely from the records.
claim: The mandatory vaccination program caused the elimination of smallpox deaths.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Vaccination (X) provides biological immunity, which directly prevents the disease (Y) through clear medical mechanisms. This is a strong interventional claim.

scenario: A state gives 40 acres of land to every veteran of the last war. Total agricultural acreage in the state increases by 20% over the next decade.
claim: Giving land to veterans causes an increase in total agricultural output.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While the grants (X) increased the number of farmers, the rise in output (Y) might be due to better tools or the fact that they were farming newly available, high-quality land (Z).

scenario: To curb religious fervor, a governor bans all public display of religious icons. Within a month, the province erupts in the largest riots in its history.
claim: Banning religious icons caused the riots.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) directly attacked a core social identity, which is a known causal trigger (Z) for civil unrest and rioting (Y).

scenario: A country establishes a national bank with the power to regulate interest rates. Currency values stabilize for the next decade.
claim: Establishing a national bank causes currency stability.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is unclear if the bank (X) was the cause, or if the stability (Y) was due to a peaceful global environment and the government's pre-existing decision to stop overspending (Z).

scenario: A factory owner mandates that all workers wear steel helmets. After the mandate, the number of workers treated in the infirmary for head injuries goes up by 25%. He decides helmets are dangerous and bans them.
claim: Helmets cause an increase in workplace head injuries.
label: NO
gold_rationale: Without helmets (X), workers likely died from head impacts and weren't 'treated' (Y). With helmets, they survive and appear in the infirmary records (Z). The helmets (X) actually increased survival, not injury risk.

scenario: An autocratic king bans all coffee houses because he believes they are hotbeds of sedition. Three years later, his reign is still stable with no major conspiracies.
claim: Banning coffee houses causes political stability.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: Stability (Y) might be due to the ban (X), but it's just as likely due to general repression or a lack of competent opposition leaders (Z) during that period.

scenario: An empire conducts its first comprehensive census to track population and assets. Tax revenues double the following year despite no change in tax rates.
claim: Conducting a census causes an increase in tax revenue collection.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The census (X) provides the state with information (Z) on previously hidden taxpayers and assets. This directly enables more comprehensive collection (Y).

scenario: A historian argues that if the American colonies had not won the Revolutionary War, the French Revolution would never have occurred due to a lack of inspiration and a less bankrupt French crown.
claim: The American Revolution was a necessary condition for the French Revolution.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While the American victory (X) was a trigger, the internal structural problems in France (Z) were so severe that a revolution (Y) might have happened regardless, driven by different triggers.

scenario: The 1918 Spanish Flu killed millions. Some say if the flu had never happened, the peace negotiations for World War I would have been much more stable and less vindictive.
claim: If the 1918 pandemic had been avoided, the post-WWI peace would have been stable.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The deep-seated nationalist rivalries and territorial disputes (Z) were the primary drivers of the harsh peace terms. The pandemic (X) was an additional stressor, but its removal wouldn't have negated the fundamental causes of instability (Y).

scenario: A specific telegram detailing an alliance between Germany and Mexico was intercepted. If it hadn't been, the US might not have entered WWI in 1917.
claim: The interception of the Zimmerman Telegram caused the timing of US entry into WWI.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The telegram (X) was the specific catalyst that shifted American public opinion (Z), leading directly to the declaration of war (Y). Removing it would have removed the immediate reason for the shift.

scenario: If the Black Death had not killed a third of Europe's population, feudalism would have survived for another 300 years because labor would have remained cheap and plentiful.
claim: The Black Death was the necessary cause of the end of feudalism.
label: NO
gold_rationale: While the plague (X) accelerated it, the rise of merchant classes and urbanization (Z) was already beginning to undermine feudal structures (Y). (Z) would have eventually caused the same outcome.

scenario: If the atomic bombs had not been used in 1945, a land invasion of Japan would have cost over a million lives.
claim: The use of atomic bombs was necessary to prevent a million casualties in a land invasion.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is counterfactually uncertain if Japan would have surrendered due to the Soviet entry or a blockade (Z) before a land invasion (Y) became necessary. The necessity of (X) is still debated by historians.

scenario: A specific hurricane in 1780 destroyed a fleet. If the hurricane hadn't happened, the naval balance in the Caribbean would have favored the opposing side during the war.
claim: If the hurricane had not occurred, the opposing side would have won the naval campaign.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While the storm (X) was a massive event, the outcome (Y) also depended on the competence of the admirals and the speed of repairs (Z) after smaller engagements. The victory is not guaranteed.

scenario: A reformist king was assassinated by a radical group. If he had lived, his historians claim he would have successfully modernized the state and avoided the revolution that happened 20 years later.
claim: If the king had survived, the later revolution would have been avoided.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: It is counterfactually uncertain if the king (X) could have solved the structural economic issues (Z) that eventually fueled the revolution (Y), even with more time.

scenario: A crucial bridge collapsed during a retreat, causing an entire army to be captured. If the bridge had been maintained properly, the army would have escaped.
claim: If the bridge had not collapsed, the army would have successfully retreated.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The bridge was the only exit (Z). Removing the collapse (X) restoring the path to safety, logically allowing the retreat (Y) to succeed in this contingent scenario.

scenario: A scientist discovered a vaccine but hid it for 20 years because of religious fear. If he had shared it immediately, thousands of lives would have been saved during the intervening two decades.
claim: If the vaccine had been released early, thousands of deaths would have been prevented.
label: YES
gold_rationale: Since the technology existed (X), its application would have directly activated the immunity mechanism (Z) to save lives (Y). The counterfactual is logically sound.

scenario: A major peace treaty was signed in 1900. Some argue if the negotiators had failed to reach an agreement, a continental war would have broken out ten years earlier than WWI.
claim: If the 1900 treaty had failed, the Great War would have started in 1904.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: While tension was high, it is counterfactually uncertain if a specific failure (X) would lead to war (Y) at that exact time, as different alliances (Z) might have shifted to preserve a temporary peace.
